Article.ArticleTitle: Electrospun SnO<sub>2</sub>/WO<sub>3</sub> Heterostructure Nanocomposite Fiber for Enhanced Acetone Vapor Detection.

AbstractText: Volatile organic compounds (VOCs), often invisible but potentially harmful, are prevalent in industrial and laboratory settings, posing health risks. Detecting VOCs in real-time with high sensitivity and low detection limits is crucial for human health and safety. The optical sensor, utilizing the gasochromic properties of sensing materials, offers a promising way of achieving rapid responses in ambient environments. In this study, we investigated the heterostructure of SnO<sub>2</sub>/WO<sub>3</sub> nanoparticles and employed it as the primary detection component. Using the electrospinning technique, we fabricated a sensing fiber containing Ag NPs, poly(methyl methacrylate) (PMMA), and SnO<sub>2</sub>/WO<sub>3</sub> (PMMA-Ag-SnO<sub>2</sub>/WO<sub>3</sub>) for acetone vapor detection. Following activation via UV/ozone treatment, we observed charge migration between WO<sub>3</sub> and SnO<sub>2</sub>, resulting in a substantial generation of superoxide radicals on SnO<sub>2</sub> nanoparticles. This phenomenon facilitates structural deformation of the fiber and alters the oxidation state of tungsten ions, ultimately leading to a significant change in extinction when exposed to acetone vapor. As a result, PMMA-Ag-SnO<sub>2</sub>/WO<sub>3</sub> fiber achieves a detection limit of 100 ppm and a response time of 1.0 min for acetone detection. These findings represent an advancement in the development of sensitive and selective VOC sensing devices.
